head.title: Pierce Public Schools - Impact of COVID-19 on Students

meta.content: Pierce Public Schools - Impact of COVID-19 on Students

Class of 2020 Graduation Ceremony
by Klarissa Norris
The COVID-19 pandemic has affected large and small scale events across the globe, and more recently and locally, the Pierce High School graduation ceremony.

span.span: Class of 2020 Graduation Ceremony
by Klarissa Norris
The COVID-19 pandemic has affected large and small scale events across the globe, and more recently and locally, the Pierce High School graduation ceremony.

Coronavirus has brought a painful end to senior year at Pierce High. The pandemic has forced schools to abruptly cancel their spring terms in a matter of days, making the last moments of the academic year especially bittersweet. For soon-to-be graduates in many high schools, the pandemic threatens to impact several meaningful milestones and events such as graduation, prom, and other end-of-year celebrations that would’ve brought together family and friends before the class of 2020 moves onto the next chapter of their lives. Several area schools have postponed commencement ceremonies due to coronavirus, and Pierce is included with those schools.
Luckily, Pierce has not yet canceled the commencement ceremony for the class of 2020. Pierce High principal Mark Brahmer has said, “If May won’t work, we’ll try

for June or July. If those two months won’t work, we’ll shoot for December when college students are done with their fall semester. We will hold a graduation ceremony at some point for all our seniors and their families.”
Many students, like the seniors at Pierce High, were stripped of the chance to say proper goodbyes or make the most of what should’ve been their final days in high school.

Senior Sydney Erikson commented on the effect COVID-19 has had on graduation and the senior class, “I definitely, like many of us, feel disappointed that graduation has been postponed but I do think it’s better than canceling graduation altogether. I also think a lot of the seniors understand why it’s important to postpone graduation and keep people safe during this unheard-of time. Although the past month of my senior year has become something almost unimaginable it will definitely be something I will never forget!”
Needless to say, coronavirus has ensured that graduation will be a memorable moment for very different reasons this year.
Student Life Then vs Now
by Taylor Compton
The Coronavirus outbreak has changed many lives, especially those of students because students’ sleeping schedules, classes, and homework schedules have all been changed since the outbreak.

Student’s lives have changed a lot since the Coronavirus outbreak. Students have to change their lives every way, shape, or form. For instance, students who usually wake up around 6 to 7 a.m. on a normal school day are now waking up way later. The time students wake up now is anywhere from 8 a.m. to noon. But students are also going to bed way later than usual. Students on a normal school day go to bed from either 9 to 11 p.m. where now they are going to bed from 10 p.m. to 4 a.m.

Student’s school life has also changed a lot. Students on a normal school schedule would have to attend class every day where now they have the option to go to their zoom meeting with their teachers. A lot of the students are attending the zoom meetings because they have questions to ask their teachers.
Sophomore Makinzie Parsons comments on the zoom classes by saying, “The online classes aren’t bad. I just feel I learn better, and it’s easier in the classroom.”

But what about their homework life, how is that going? Well, most students have been staying busy with homework. But the time they do their homework has definitely changed. Sophomore Callie Arnold says that her homework experience “Has been going pretty well. It’s just having the motivation to do your homework.”

Students have the option now to do homework at any time of the day. Obviously, not every student is the same as some students love to get their homework over with in the morning so they have the rest of the day to do what they want. Other students like to do their homework throughout the day and just do some of it and then take breaks when they like. But on a normal day of school, most students do their homework during study hall or anywhere from 4 to 8 p.m.

Sophomore Aundrea Huber says this about her whole online school experience, “I think the homework and online classes are going well, but I wish all of the teachers had a document for everyone to look at and see what was actually due because I sometimes I have a hard time keeping track of everything that is due.”
The Coronavirus outbreak has truly changed the lives of students
Staying Connected
by MacKenzie Peters

In a time like this, when we are expected to shut off nearly all unnecessary human contact, it can be kind of difficult to stay connected with the world around us. Fortunately, technology has made it a little easier for that to happen.

During this pandemic, certain apps have been getting quite a spotlight. One of the most common is Zoom, which is an app used largely by teachers and businesses to stay connected without having to be in the same room. Similar to FaceTime, Zoom allows for numerous people to video chat from nearly any location.
College student Ellie Peters speaks on how she uses Zoom to continue her education during this time.
“It allows me to be more interactive than other online methods, but I would still rather be in the classroom.”

Aside from Zoom, simple social media programs like Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, and news apps have been used to keep people informed not only on the progress of this virus, but also just on each other’s lives.
Elizabeth Hammer, a Pierce High student, says,

“It’s really hard to keep in touch with everyone during these times because I would always see my friends during school but apps like FaceTime and Snapchat have really been nice because I get to see my friends face-to-face and we get to talk all day”
So, while this pandemic is making it much more difficult to keep in touch, we are fortunate enough to have technology that allows for much more socialization, even if it isn’t face-to-face.
Keeping Yourself Entertained
by Elizabeth Hammer
During these hard times stuck at home, it can be hard to keep yourself entertained or hard to think of new things to do.

When quarantine first started, I wasn’t very bored because it felt like just an extended weekend. I would just relax around the house, watch tv, babysit my many sisters, or maybe even workout. However, now that we have been in quarantine for awhile, it is very boring, and I am tired of doing the same things over and over.

So, I have tried to try out new things to keep myself busy. Now, I try to bake some type of dessert at least once a week. For example, this week I made brownies with chocolate frosting on top. I also have been drawing more. These past couple months or so I haven’t drawn as much as I used to, but now with all my free time I have finally gotten back at it. Of course there are some days where I don’t feel like doing anything, so those days I try to watch movies or shows that I haven’t seen in awhile or that I have never seen. Most days I try to work out as well. Even if it is just a little workout, I still try to squeeze it in because with all the eating I have been doing, every second counts.

However, the two things I do the most during this time off is clean and watch my sisters. Before quarantine even happened my father always made me clean a lot, but now we clean even more. My father and my step mom also still work off and on so that leaves me to watch my younger sisters almost everyday as well. I think this has brought us all closer though as well because my family and I do try to have game nights.

All in all, it is important to try new things and keep yourself entertained during these hard times. Whether it's trying something new or picking up on an old hobby, we need to keep entertained and keep our spirits up.
Back to School… Kind Of
by Autumn Hanna

The students of Pierce are back to school, but not traditionally. All of Pierce High’s 9-12 students are now required to do online work assigned by their teachers. This is obviously something completely new to both the teachers and students of Pierce High School.

There, of course, are mixed feelings about online school work. Some students frankly learn better in person. Junior Hannah Whitmore states, “I think online learning is going to be harder for a lot of students. Some people need structure and more accountability.”
Teachers assign work twice a week to students, which is due for a grade when instructed by the teachers.

Nobody expected this to be how they would finish their 2019-2020 school year, especially the seniors. Senior Jenna Brown says, “This is definitely not how I planned my senior year to go, but I do think it’s great we are doing online work to finish out the school year. I personally prefer learning in the classroom and having access to teachers and other resources easier, but I think the school is doing the best they can.”
Through some trial and error, everyone should get more comfortable and used to this change.
